description:
Establishing a portal to another world is a major milestone by any yardstick. The Constellars are often tasked with the conveyance of armies across realms during wars and this ability is crucial to their role.

Setting up and preparing for the ritual is the easy part, the real challenge comes in maintaining a delicate balance of the cosmic forces as one disrupts the fabric of space and time so that others may arrive at their intended destination safely.

TKG ARENA: A Rift of Portals is a game for 1 player.

Components required for this game:

WORLD TILES:    48
OINKS:    15 from each element for each player (Default)

Winning Conditions

The objective of the game is to stabilize the portal once it is set up and this is represented by fulfilling a number of conditions.

1.    The number of Oinks in the Inner Gate must be equal or more than the Oinks placed in the Outer Void.
2.    The number of elemental insignias placed on any linear sides of the Boundary must be equal.
3.    The elemental insignias on each tile must be matched by a placed Oink representing the same element.

Ending Condition

The game ends when all tiles are played and all unmatched Oinks on any tile on the Boundary are moved to the Outer Void. The player loses when the winning conditions are not achieved when the game ends.

Setup

A player starts the game by drawing randomly from a stack of world tiles to be placed in a 3 x 3 grid manner as below.

X        A    B    C        O
        D    I    E        
        F    G    H

1.    Shuffle the 48 world tiles into a stack. World tiles are referred to as tiles.

2.    Draw 3 tiles from the stack. From these 3 tiles, flip 1 over to the grid side to form the Outer Void (This is represented by the faced down tile O in the diagram), 1 to form the Inner Gate (This is represented by the faced down tile I in the diagram).

3.    Gain the Oinks matched by the elemental insignias of the last remaining tile and discard it, an area such as X can be designated for discarded tiles in the diagram.

All world tiles built are placed faced up with their elemental insignias visible. Tiles A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H surrounding tile I forms the Boundary. To fulfill winning condition 2,  the sum of the number of elemental insignias on the Tiles A, B, C; Tiles C,E, H; Tiles F,G, H and Tiles A, D, F are equal.

On each turn

Draw 3 tiles from the stack and the player must perform ONE of each of the following actions in the following order:

1.    Gain - Play a tile, gain the Oinks indicated on the elemental insignias and discard it. Put the Oinks gained in the Inner Gate.

2.    Build - Build a tile, if it is the first tile, place it adjacent to the Inner Gate, if it is not, it must be placed adjacent to another tile that has been built that bears at least one of its own elemental insignias. If the intended location is adjacent to two or more world tiles, then all adjacent world tiles must bear at least one matching elemental insignia between them.

If you are unable to or do not wish to build for any reason, gain the Oinks indicated on any one of the remaining tiles that has not been played and put them into the Outer Void. You can also replace any tile built with any tile in your hand but all Oinks placed on the built tile will be placed in the Outer Void.

3.    Move - Play a tile, you can move Oinks indicated on the elemental insignias of this tile from the Inner Gate to any built tile, or to move any Oink from a built tile to an adjacent built tile. If you are unable to or do not wish to move any of the Oinks indicated for any reason, gain the Oinks instead and put them into the Outer Void.

The player cannot skip any action and each action must be fulfilled in totality. E.g.  During a Move action, a tile with 3 Fire Insignias has been chosen but the player has only 1 Fire Oink in the Inner Gate. You may NOT move the existing 1 Fire Oink to any other tile, gain 2 Fire Oinks and then placed them in the Outer Void. 3 Fire Oinks should be gained and placed in the Outer Void.

Scoring

For each Oink placed in a tile that bears the same insignia, gain 1 Victory Point. The player with the most Victory Points wins the final victory if multiple players are competing. Ties are broken by the difference in Oinks between their Outer Void and Inner Gate. The player with the greater difference wins. If the differences are the same, the players shared a joint victory.

Variant

The game can be scaled up with a BOUNDARY with sides featuring more tiles. (E.g 4 or 5). The rest of the rules remain unchanged. In this case, players can choose to leave the space representing the Inner Gate empty instead of a faced down tile I. Players can choose to use other appropriate counters to represent Oinks during play.

In Civilia, players place down overlapping cards to make groups of symbols and expand their civilization. The player that builds the largest group of a symbol becomes World Leader in that sector.

Exploit your superiority by planning and achieving to score points before your opponents take back the advantage! Score final points after the last card is drawn and the player with the most points wins.

C*NT is a four letter swear word dice game where the last player out is the C*NT! There are 4 lettered dice, each die has a wild card '*' on it. The included swear list score pad has 4 columns of 10 offensive four letter words, one column for each player. The words further down the list are more difficult to throw (statistically), C*NT at the bottom, being the hardest to throw.

In turns, each player bids to get control of the dice or passes. A bid consists of a number of throws and a swear word from the swear list. Each subsequent bid must be a fewer number of throws and/or a harder word to throw than the previous bid. When everyone else passes the last bidder wins control of the dice, they are now the Tosser.

The Tosser takes the dice and tries to throw the bid swear word within the stated number of tosses. If the word is thrown then the Tosser can cross off that word (or the first remaining word above it) from their swear list. If they have crossed off all their words, they go out, otherwise they start the next bidding round. If they did not throw their swear word, all the other players cross off their highest remaining swear word above and including the bid word, then the player to the left starts the next bidding round.

If at any time four asterisks are thrown then all the other player go out immediately. The last player "out" is a C*NT, everyone points at the C*NT and shouts "C*NT". The C*NT buys the next round of drinks, etc.

Astro Knights is a cooperative deck building game where your deck is never shuffled. Your goal is to defeat the Boss before it destroys your team or the Homeworld you’re defending.

Each round, the players and the Boss will take turns in a random order. During a player’s turn, they will be able to acquire Fuel, Tech, and Weapons from the supply, equip and attack with those Weapons based on the number of slots they have, gain new slots, power up, and use their special ability. All four of the Bosses in this game have their own decks and abilities, and will require a different strategy to be defeated

Today the forest inhabitants hold a sports festival! The crowd is greaeting the athletes. Ready, Steady, Go! But what's the news: the competition is not that fair. Try on the role of detective! Find out who was the only true winner of the race. To know all the details, you'll have to discuss the story with all the animals in the game. After the game you are going to answer a few questions and find out what really happened. Play as a team, discuss the story, and get to the bottom of it!

This is a cooperative detective board game for the whole family. You will literally piece together the event (connect several cards to get the full picture) and attempt to get it right. After the game you are going to answer a few questions and find out what really happened. Play as a team, discuss the story, and get to the bottom of it!

The players lay cards in a 3x4 grid out on the table. New cards must be connected to the starting cards like a jigsaw puzzle so that in the end there's a complete picture on the table. The game begins with 2 starting cards placed in the center of the table. Then there is a deck with all the other cards. Players need to lay out the 4 top cards next to the deck pics down.

On their turns, they need to pick 2 out of 5 cards (1 top from the deck and 4 next to it). Look at them and decide, whether the info on the cards is useful or not. If it is useful, they connect these to the starting ones. If not, discarded. Then it's the nest turn, and so on.
Players need to discuss the cards to decide

When the story has come to an end, there should be a complete picture of cards. Players need to discuss the plot to decide on the cards to lay out or discard. After that players should answer 6 questions about the event. Who did that, why, etc. Check their answers with the finishing cards. The team wins when they managed to answer all 6 questions correctly AND laid out the cards with the correct details in the puzzle.

The Power of the Word is a board game where you can learn stories about the Lord Jesus and spend a great time with your family or friends.

The game is introduced by a story about people who are looking for treasures. They found the chest with fragments of priceless woven paintings depicting scenes from the Gospel. Now the treasure is in the hands of the players. They have beautiful, multi-colored cards with scenes from the Gospel in front of them, as well as pictures and words from the Bible.

On their turn, they decide which dice to roll and which cards to draw. They should do this in such a way as to create the highest scoring collections.

The winner is the one who scores the most points and reaches the finish line with his pawn the fastest.


Moc SÅ‚owa to gra planszowa, dziÄ™ki której moÅ¼na poznaÄ‡ opowieÅ›ci o Panu Jezusie i spÄ™dziÄ‡ doskonaÅ‚y czas z rodzinÄ… lub przyjacióÅ‚mi.Do gry wprowadza historia o ludziach, którzy poszukujÄ… skarbów. OdnaleÅºli skrzyniÄ™, a w niej fragmenty bezcennych, tkanych obrazów, ukazujÄ…cych sceny z Ewangelii.
Teraz skarb znajduje siÄ™ w rÄ™kach graczy. MajÄ… przed sobÄ… piÄ™kne, wielobarwne karty ze scenami z Ewangelii, a takÅ¼e obrazki i sÅ‚owa z Biblii. W swojej turze decydujÄ…, którÄ… kostkÄ… rzuciÄ‡ i które dobraÄ‡ karty. Powinni to zrobiÄ‡ w taki sposób, by utworzyÄ‡ najwyÅ¼ej punktowane kolekcje.

Wygra ten, kto zdobÄ™dzie najwiÄ™cej punktów i najszybciej dotrze swoim pionkiem do mety.

Gra rozwija spostrzegawczoÅ›Ä‡, myÅ›lenie strategiczne i przede wszystkim wiedzÄ™ biblijnÄ….
Poznaj BibliÄ™. Odkrywaj Moc Biblijnego SÅ‚owa.

A children's storytelling game, where players are presented with a basic narrative arc which informs them of what they need to accomplish. Each player has his own character with which he explores the map by opening new hexagon tiles and finding different items. These serve as inspiration and opportunity to tell a story and progress thorugh the game towards it narrative finale.

On a turn, a player rolls a die which tells him how many action points he gets to use. As an action, he can open a new tile, move to an adjacent tile, or pick up an item from the tile he is on. There's also a possibility he gets to use his special power. All this should be narrated as well. The game ends when all the story cards are completed, that is, a set amount of items in requested colours are collected. The players win together, I noted the game is cooperative. But I guess, there is no winning as such, as the game is about telling a story, there is no mechanical challenge.

In Europa Tour, each player starts in Amsterdam and tries to complete their trip; East, West, South or North, through Europe as quick as possible.  The aim of the game is to make his journey through Europe as quickly as possible by adding the city cards of your route in the correct sequence to your route. Each route visits 16 European cities and requires 8 Visa cards at certain specific points of the route for border crossings. You win the game by being the first player to finish your route and end up back in Amsterdam.

The game starts with every player in Amsterdam, the other 96 cards of all four routes (16 city cards and 8 visa cards per route) are then shuffled and put into a grid formation on the table.

During their turn, a player flips 2 cards of their choice and if they fit, extend their trip by adding the cards to their line.

If one or both of the cards are part of your trip but not adjacent to the city you are in, you can safe the card(s) by switching it/them with another one (logically with a card in the grid close to you). At the end of your turn, you flip back all cards.

Some advancements of the routes require visa cards which need to be placed before you are able to advance, and the visa cards are shared between North & East and shared between South & West. Visa cards cannot be saved. The end point of Amsterdam can also not be saved.

This game can be summarized as a game of memory, where you can safe cards for later use and where their is a small competition for visa cards between players (South&West and North&East).

4th Street Basketball recreates the excitement of NBA or collegiate action by maximizing your team's talents against your opponent's. Use the driving, passing, defensive, rebounding, and shooting skills of your individually-rated players to magnify their team's productivity. Concepts include ball movement, defensive play (man-to-man, zone, press) and shooting in 3 different levels.

On their turn, each player rolls five color-coded six-sided dice that can determine a variety of actions: player match-ups, offensive play setups, and even the offensive plays themselves. As per the rules of standard NBA or collegiate basketball, the highest score at the end of the game wins.

Based on the earth-shattering Empyre event, this HeroClix miniatures game contains the Avengers, Fantastic Four, X-Men, and more!

Play up to 8 campaign scenarios for 2 players where results matter from session to session or sit down for a head to head single match of raw power! Each of the 10 beautiful ready to play figures comes with two different ways to play for hundreds of different combinations. Excellent point of entry for the first time miniatures player! Map components are thick double sided tiles and the box includes everything you need to play!

This boxed-set is a great way for 2 players to learn HeroClix! Existing players will definitely want to pick up this product since it includes tournament-worthy figures and interesting scenario gameplay!

I arrive, I run, I fly!

No, you don't arrive, you don't run, you crawl. But it's perfect for this very original snail race where the slowest one wins. An ode to slowness which is good in our society where everything has become urgent. The color of your snail is secret.

On your turn, roll the 4 colored dice. Each dice allows you to move a snail if it is of the indicated color or if it is on a flower of the color of the dice.

Try to move the other players' snails without revealing yourself too much. If the other players spot you, they might make you finish first.

The player who finishes first, loses.

Gather Your Party  is a 2-4 player tavern party game where you and your friends compete to gain the most Reputation in the tavern. Recruit Patrons, Send Drink Tokens, Complete Quests and avoid all perils of a night out at the tavern.

To win, players will have to manage how much Reputation they have, and how much they Drink.

Get four (4) Reputation, win the game. Get four (4) Drink tokens, get knocked out.

Players will take turns adding Patrons to their parties, completing Quests and avoid getting too drunk. Once you gain enough Reputation from completing Quests, you become a Drinking Legend and win the game.

Alternatively, you can drink your friends under-the-table and become the last player standing. There are many different Patrons and Events cards that give and take away Drinks, but essentially, if you hit your limit of 4 Drink Tokens, you are knocked out of the game.

Monsters given the name of Clad have brought devastation upon humanity. However, they also hold a valuable resource known as magic stones. The only ones able to face them are witches given the power of future sight, who compete for the most fame. Players take control of these witches trying to complete missions and gain the most magic stones from the Clad.

Each player uses a personal deck of cards which they can upgrade each time they cycle through. Each turn, draw from your deck to a hand of three cards. Play cards to maneuver your witch around the board, attack, and use other effects. The three attacks the Clad will unleash each round are always visible beforehand. Players draft for turn order, playing between each of the boss turns, so planning around where the boss will move and attack when your turn comes around becomes key. Each point of damage dealt to the Clad gets you a magic stone. After nine rounds, whoever has the most victory points from magic stones and cards in their deck wins the game.

Operation RI is a print and play wargame of moderate complexity for one or two players, simulating the Japanese overland advance on Port Moresby in 1942 and the subsequent Allied counter-offensive.

Components (need to be printed, the counters require assembly):

Rulebook

Charts and tables

Set up cards

2 x maps (recommended print size 11" x 17" each)

1 x half sheet of double-sided unit counters and markers (74 combat units and 12 markers)

1 x half sheet of double-sided strength markers (88 strength markers)

Historical background and designer's notes

Comprehensive and illustrated examples of play

Scale: battalion and company

Map: point-to-point movement

Time frame: weekly turns

Solitaire suitability: very high

Design features: battle fatigue, jungle and mountain warfare, Allied air transport, Japanese bunker defences.

The Japanese have a chance to capture Port Moresby via the overland route using their seasoned infantry from the South Seas Force. The terrain will make it a difficult task. If they fail, the Allied forces will launch a counter-attack with the aim of driving the Japanese into the sea.

The system focuses on the effect prolonged periods of combat in difficult terrain had on combat units. Units which fight for too long without respite are vulnerable to counter-attack. Each side must manage their forces with respect to fatigue, which represents combat exhaustion and ammunition expenditure, and the inherent logistical difficulties this campaign posed.

Can the Japanese capture Port Moresby? In this simulation they can, but it is difficult.

Also challenging is the task of crushing the Japanese beachheads on the north coast.

Purchase via direct digital download at : https://www.wargamevault.com/product/379181/Operation-RI?src=hottest

Turncoats is a competitive game for 2-5 players, where three factions are at war. The players take on the role of Aspirants and Interlopers, not obviously tied to any one group. Instead, they must manage their loyalties, represented by stones in their hand that they keep hidden from everyone else.

During the game, players spend stones from their hand to take actions with the matching faction. However, they need to keep a tight eye on their remaining stones and the tiebreakers, as at the end of the game, the winning faction will choose the player with the most stones remaining in their hand as the new ruler.

In the taberns of Aguacatata, mercenaries play a unique card game: Cardfrontation!

Each player controls two pawns. Move them to gather resources and craft weapons, equip these weapons on the left or right hand an attack your opponent to bring their life to 0!

Cardfrontation is a position based and resource management card combat game where two players compete in order to do the maximum damage to the opponent. Use strong weapons, powerful staff and tricky artifacts to win in this strategy driven game.

The nuclear apocalypse has struck, leaving the world's culinary supply in shambles. Choose a Survivor to battle it out for new nuclear delicacies while wielding hilarious makeshift weapons fueled with ridiculous visual puns to combat your opponents.
 Hostile Hoarders is a game of war and self preservation for 2-5 players. Each survivor plays 4 weapon cards face down in front of them. Choose from one of your attacking weapon cards and pair it with an opponent's defending weapon card. Compare your attacking power to their defending power. The winner of the battle has prevailed and collects their reward. If the attacking player has conquered, they receive a meal that day, collecting one ration card. If the defender has bested the battle, they flip their defending weapon back face down and steal thee attacker’s weapon for their own, adding it to their hand.

Various instants can be added to aid in the skirmish.
When you have depleted all of your fellow survivor’s defense, go in for the kill. Attack a player with no facedown cards in front of them, and collect their survivor card as a reward. No food, only glory. When all other survivors are eliminated or a player has collected 10 ration points, you are the glutton of the apocalypse.

—description from the publisher

Zip Zap Zop is a unique combination of deck-building and trick-taking that allows players to play a trick-taking game where they decide what cards they get dealt. This new concept gives the agency and strategy of a deck-building game, while maintaining the quick-paced, tactical nature of a trick-taking game.

The theme is integrated throughout, with players taking on the role of comedians in an improv show. The card play has the players interacting with each other in an improv scene and the new cards they buy are suggestions from the audience for the next scene.

Zip Zap Zop’s trick-taking follows the rules of a standard trick-taker, with a few differences:


     You may be able to play more than 1 card to the trick.
     Some cards are modifiers that modify a played card.
     If a player ever plays the same number as the previous card, then that player may play an additional card to the trick. The played cards then add, forming a new number.
     After playing tricks, players will buy cards using the number of tricks they won as currency.

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Atlanta, GA depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

—user summary

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Boulder, CO depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

—user summary

A trivia game inspired by the TV series FRIENDS. You spin the Wheel of Mayhem to go up the Ladder of Chance. You go past the Mud Hut, through the Rainbow Ring to get to the Golden Monkey. You yank his tail and BOOM! You're in Paradice Pond!

—description from the publisher

Pokémon racing game with flying, dragons, fire, electric, and bug Pokémon. "Gotta scratch 'em all!"

In this scratch off game, two players scratch off a square on the track, revealing Pokémon, Team Rocket, treasures, etc. Depending on the revealed icon, players get to scratch off other sections of the card and potentially score points. Whoever collects the most points wins the game.

For solo games, the player plays both sides until a winner is determined.

Tiki Toss: Adventure Island is a tropical tiki themed dexterity game combined with a traditional roll and move game in which up to 6 players race to be the first to return to the starting point after collecting a set of 5 different colored ring cards. Players earn ring cards at launching pad locations spread across the board. Once at one of these locations, players draw a corresponding ring card and successfully complete all instructions listed on the card. This usually requires players to make one or more successful tiki tosses. A tiki toss consists of a player swinging a metal ring, so that it catches on a hook attached to a tiki pole in the middle of the game board. As players move along paths to and from the different Launching Pads, they will encounter tiki heads that may help or hinder their progress.

—user summary

Your Village is in trouble with the Tiki Forces that be!  They are angry and demand 5 Precious Rings in order to spare the Village.  Two to Six Villagers are chosen to brave the dangers of Tiki Toss Adventure Island but there can only be one Hero! Can you be the first to collect the five rings (Gold, Silver, Ruby, Emerald, Coral) and return them to the village?

In order to collect the 5 rings, Players must embark on a journey through Quicksand Beach, The Isle of Fire, The Fourth Sister, The Ghost of the Galleon and Head Hunter Hill.  Along the way, Tiki Toss skills are essential! Although each player must beware of Sirens, Eruptions, being sentenced to the Pit and more, the biggest challenges can come from an opponent! You may be skipped, reversed or have a ring stolen by an opponent at any time! Trust no one. The stakes are high and the race back to the Village is on!

To be the Hero requires a balance of Luck and Skill!  The Dice may be on your side and you may draw the right cards, but do you have the skills of a Tiki Toss Master? Can you handle the pressure?

—description from the publisher

What does it take to be a victorious vendor of Plushie Pier? Selling lots of plushie sets, letting buyers haggle a bit, and boosting POMP! POMP is a local acronym for “place On My Pier.” It basically reflects the popularity, charisma, and overall esteem of your Craft.

Using the cards overlapping mechanic, player for prices of plushies on the pier for sale.
Each time you make a sale, you get a score card matching the icon and quantity of that set. If a player has sold their 8th Plushie, players complete the final round and score.

—description from the designer

It should be easy to name 3 Disney dogs - but can you do it under the pressure of 5 seconds twisting down, and with the other players staring at you, waiting for you to get flustered? Time's not on your side, so just say what comes to mind and risk ridiculous answers slipping out as time twirls down on the unique twisted timer! It's all in good fun with this fast-paced game where you have to "Just Spit It Out!"

Explore the wilds of the North from dewy dawn to dreamy dusk. Keep your camera ready as the most impressive panorama wins the day!

The dew glistens on the grass, the mist hangs over the valley, and the haunting bellow of a solitary moose echoes off the mountains. You’re setting off on an overnight hike, your trusty camera in your hand, in hope of capturing an image of this beautifully remote place.

Work together to build an awe-inspiring horizon. During the game, you will select cards to add to your panoramas. Art the end of the game, cards score points based on their relationships to other cards. You will also score points by winning awards.

Panorama is easy to learn with elegant rules! Choose a card from your hand, add it to one of your panoramas, then pass the rest to your neighbor. Cards score based on other cards in your panoramas!

—description from the publisher

Competitive card game for 1-6 players. Two beautifully illustrated decks with unique scoring mechanics. Panorama uses a card drafting and semi-cooperative tableau-building mechanic similar to that found in Between Two Cities, but in this case building horizontal panoramas.

Argy Bargey is a new board game where you compete to create your own canal empire.

Each player must complete routes between towns and cities, competing against each other. Using tiles, you'll want your waterway to take the fastest possible route across the board.

Just like real canals, you'll need to use locks and tunnels to tackle hills. Junctions will be needed to connect other canals and create an efficient network.

With an approximate playing time of 45 minutes, 2 to 6 people can gather to do battle - canal style! Can you become the greatest canal tycoon of the 21st century?

This game was made by wholesale store "Makro" (or "Metro" in Germany) for their 25 year anniversary in the Netherlands. You play this trivia game with 2 to 4 teams of each 2 to 4 players in it. Every team put their pawn (a brain) on the start position. The first team to reach the finish wins.

During your turn you will pick the top card from the pile. On each card there are 2 themes, one on each side of the card, and you have 10 seconds to decide which side you want to play.

After choosing the side you want to play, you get 60 seconds to guess the words written on the card which belong to the theme on the top of the card (Dutch writers, capital cities, Makro employer titles, types of cheese). The team to the right of the playing team is the control team, which tallies how many correct answers are given.

The answers are written on the card but have a red coating over them which makes them almost invisible to read, the game also features a pair of sunglasses with red-tainted glasses which can see through the coating and can read the correct answers (this pair of sunglasses is for the control team).

If no correct answer is given in the first 30 seconds, the first answer is given by the control team as a hint, this answer does not count towards the score. After the 60 seconds are over, the playing team moves their pawn as many spots as their score and then the control team becomes the new playing team.

Furthermore, some spots on the board have a special action like "Go back 3 spots", which goes into effect immediately when a team lands on it, or "if you can at least 5 correct answers next turn, move one extra spot forward" or "Lose a turn", which goes into effect on their next turn. The board has 48 spaces, including the start and the finish space.

In this Trivia game about the European Union and its member states, players try to answer questions correctly in order to continue their turn, but if they guess wrong, they might give their opponents an extra turn!

Every player starts on the starting spot.
The player who rolls the highest with the die starts the game.
In your turn, you roll the die and move that amount of places.
You can land on either: 

     a flag from a country, you then answer a question about the country who belongs to that flag
     a spot on the map of a country, you then answer a question about that country
     a Star, you then answer a question about the European Union


If you guess correctly, you get and extra turn and can roll again.
If you guess wrong, the next player can try to answer correctly, if any of the other players guess correctly, they save up an extra turn that they can use after their normal turn, but they do not move right now and the turn of the current player is over (unless they saved up an extra turn between their last turn and this one).
If no one answers the question correctly, the turn of the current player is over, unless that player has saved up extra turns between their last turn and this one.
You can save up at most 2 extra turns.

Questions from countries can be in their native language (Finnish, Swedish, Danish, English, German, French, Luxembourgian, Austrian) or they are in Dutch.

When a player reaches or goes over the finish spot, they have to answer one last question about the European Union to win the game. If they answer incorrectly they stay at their spot and get a new question about the European Union the next turn, if they guess correctly their next turn, they still win the game.

—user summary

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Columbus, GA depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Long Beach, CA depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

A roulette variant with pig motifs on the bidding cards and on the roulette wheel. Each player has 4 cards in hand, with one suit and one pig position, he can bid up to four suits. Then the wheel is spun, for the winning color with matching pig position there is a winning pig and the bet card, for the right color with wrong pig there is a triple chance card, for the wrong color and the right pig there is a single chance card, but you have to give up the bet cards. If nothing is right, you give away all the cards you have bet. Whoever has a winning pig can challenge another owner and bets on a pig position, if he turns the right one, he gets the opponent's pig, otherwise he loses his own to the opponent. The first to own three winning pigs wins.

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Plymouth, MA depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the game board from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Waco, TX depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

An educational building block game. There are 2 types of wooden cubes: 6 emoticon blocks (each side has a different cartoon expression) and 8 geometric blocks (each side has a different geometric pattern).

Each player starts out with their own set of the chosen cube type and the corresponding deck of puzzle pattern cards face down in a stack. Pick up a card and choose the correct combination of blocks to create the picture on the card. For the victory that takes the shortest amount of time, an hourglass can help keep time.

This is a great way for children to stimulate their attention, exercise fine motor skills, enhance their hand-eye coordination, spatial imagination, logical thinking ability, and practical abilities, and cultivate their hobbies. The cubes are painted with safe, non-toxic, water-based paint.

Starry Sky Trick-Taking is a 3-player only game in which the players draw constellations on a communal board based upon the cards played to a trick. The specific path(s) drawn are determined by the majority color played and the majority high/low numbers played, and the path is drawn by the winner of the trick.

Play continues until players have 1 card left in hand.  In addition to their traditional rank, the cards also show a bid number for how many points the drawn constellations will be worth. The winner of the game is the player whose bid was closest to the value of the constellations.

Solarpunk Futures is a 10-minute rules-light role playing game where players imagine the pathways to a desirable world from the perspective of a utopian future.

Players use a deck of cards to remember Ancestors (e.g. grower, engineer, newcomer) and work together using Tools (e.g. recycled materials, equipment library, off-grid energy) and Values (e.g. care, responsibility, usufruct) to overcome a set of real-world Challenges (e.g. borders, ableist infrastructure, climate refugee crisis). Through dialogue and collaborative worldbuilding, collective and visionary narratives emerge of a new society, along with plausible scenarios for how to get there.

The players are guided through a collaborative storytelling process, imagining the pathway to their utopian future. In a conversation that can range from solemn to comical in tone, the players decide collectively how they worked together and why it took all of them to overcome the Challenge.

—description from the publisher

Help the Princess Heroes race to the castle! The castle has been cursed and all of the princesses must get through the enchanted forest and make it to the castle before the last leaf from the tree of life lands on the ground. Work together to help the princesses defeat all the obstacles and make it to the castle before the leaf reaches the ground to break the curse.

In this cooperative game, kids ages 4+ will work together to help move all of the princess heroes across the board and into the castle. Players use their item cards to move a princess onto a matching space on the board. The princesses don’t share spaces, so players can get the princesses really moving by playing the same item card twice and jumping over the other princesses. Mixed into the item cards are obstacle cards. These obstacles take time to overcome and when a player draws an obstacle card, the leaf token falls one space closer to the ground. Players must get all of the princess heroes back to the castle before the leaf token reaches the ground and the castle curse cannot be broken.

The bright and colorful image-based gameplay makes Princess Heroes easy to learn and fun to play! Once players know the rules there is no reading required, which makes this a fun way for kids to use basic strategy skills and reduces competition by having the players work together to beat the game.

-description from publisher

Race to the mountain top and convince the dragon to save the smore’s! The magical marshmallow fire in the kingdom has gone out, and it’s up to the heroes to race to the dragon’s nest and convince the dragon to help them relight the fire. Players move their hero through the lands collecting keys for hidden shortcuts and gems for the dragon, trying to be the first one to reach the dragon’s nest. Once players reach the nest, they will roll the dice and offer the dragon gems to convince them to come and help the kingdom.

In My First Dragon Adventure, kids will race through the different lands, using numbered cards to jump ahead, while trying to become the hero of the kingdom. But they better watch out! Along the way there are obstacles to avoid and gems to collect. Players move along the board by using their numbered cards to move ahead. Strategically use your cards to avoid landing on obstacles, pick up special items, and slow other players down. Once players reach the dragons nest, they roll the dice to see how the dragon will respond. The first player to make it to the nest and convince the dragon to help is the winner!

Colorful and detailed images make this story driven game a great way to help kids develop their strategic thinking and counting skills. Limited reading and basic counting make this an easy game for kids aged 5+ to learn and enjoy!

-description from publisher

The StarComm Wars is a game of economic warfare simulating the Helion wars of 2312 to 2317. Players take on the roles of merchant companies and of the ill-fated Helion Imperium in an attempt to survive and prosper.

Two introductory scenarios introduce the merchant mechanics and how to play the Imperium. There is then one short and one full campaign scenario. The game is for 2-5 players, with one player representing the Imperium, against 1-4 merchants.

The trains start at the upper right corner (train depot). Movement is determined by a die. On an uneven roll the train has to follow the blue arrow, on an even roll the red arrows. On some spaces signals und signs affect movement. Naturally the trains can not pass each other on the tracks.

The first player to get his train to the destination station (below the depot) wins the game.

—user summary
The traditional Monopoly board game but featuring locations from the Penrith area within the state of NSW, Australia.

Be the first to use all your cards to form trios, ladders or logical relationships (greater than/less than). Modify the groups already on the table, use some of your cards to create new ones, even use the joker to make combinations and modifications. Even use the joker to make combinations and modifications. Play, think and above all enjoy!

Shanzhai is a fast playing pick-up and deliver, economic game in which you’re a “businessman” dealing counterfeit goods, trying to make more money than your rivals. Get deals from the local traders, complete them by selling the required goods, maybe gamble with the money you make and see if you’re lucky enough to double your income. You need to be fast and witty though, the more deals you complete the sooner the police come, will you bribe them or completely avoid them?

Shanzhai (Chinese: å±±å¯¨; pinyin: shÄnzhài) is a Chinese term that means counterfeit products.

—description from the designer

WanderSquares is a fantasy table-top adventure game for players 9 and up. It features an ever-changing map, a choose-your-path adventure guide and 16 inspiring characters to choose from.


     An Ever-changing Map - The WanderSquares map is made up of 32 interlocking Adventure Squares. Each square is a tiny story; with monsters, puzzles and treasure. The map grows in endless combinations with each new direction the players choose. Three Special Squares contain major magic items (and mini-bosses). Recover the treasure and you'll unlock the final challenge.
     Search for Hidden Treasure - Explore each square to uncover Treasure Cards. You’ll find powerful potions, special weapons, useful gear and magical creatures that will help you in your quest.
     The Adventure Guide - Each square of the map has a matching page in the choose-your-path Adventure Guide that describes the scene and the actions the players can take. Once the players choose an action, turn the page to see what happens next.


—description from the designer

A trivia game where you get 10 clues to guess the answer.  The player may make one guess per clue to identify the person, place, or thing.  The more clues the player uses, the fewer points they earn (10 points for a correct guess on the first clue, 9 points on the second clue, 8 on the third, and so on).  Players rotate reading the clues and guessing until each player has guessed a few cards (suggested play is 4 cards per each player).  Whoever earns the highest points total wins the game.
In the trick-taking game Parrotdigm, a new scoring condition is revealed each round, with the points sometimes being positive, sometimes negative. Try to play your hand right to end up on top!

This card game contains eight families with four cards in each family. Each turn a player asks another player if he/she has one particular card. If the other player has that card he/she has to give it away to the one asking for it. Then the player can continue asking for cards. If a player don´t have the card you asking for, the turn go over to the other player. When you have all cards from one family you can put it down in front of you. The goal of the game is to collect as many sets of families as possible. The game is based on the character Doctor Snuggels created by Jeffrey O'Kelly.

Own circles should be connected by different colorful shapes.

Each player has four circles of one color - blue, pink, gray and yellow-green. One circle of each player is placed in the center together with the circle of the other players so that these circles touch each other, so to speak, form a square. The remaining circles are laid out in a circle around this center square with about a hand's width between them; there should be space between the circles and circles of the same color should not be directly adjacent or too close together. The 36 shape cards in six colors - yellow, orange, blue, purple, dark green and red - are laid out in an unordered pile, with each shape once per color.

The active player rolls the dice and takes any shape card of that color and places it on the table so that it touches a circle or another already existing shape card. If there is no matching shape card left in the supply, take any card of that color from the table and place it somewhere else. In this way, each player tries to be the first to connect his own circles with shape cards. The player who succeeds first is the immediate winner.

Cheerful, colorful, simple and an enjoyable, loose practice of spatial imagination and use of space; for example, you can put the fish and the starfish mouth to tip, or put the head of the gobbler in the crook of the starfish or mushroom - so you can overcome long distances, or avoid making it too easy for the other players to connect their own circles faster.
